Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of the Intelligent River (R), A Basin-Scale Monitoring Instrument

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: 11-26344
PI(s): Hallstrom, Jason
Edison, Gene; Geist, Robert; Goasguen, Sebastian: Post, Christopher
Institution: Clemson University
Title: MRI/Dev: Dev of the Intelligent River (R), a Basin-Scale Monitoring Instrument
Project Proposed:
This project, developing a river and water-resource consisting of a sensor network that forms an intelligent sensor fabric on a river basin, aims to provide real-time access to essential environmental and hydrological parameters at appropriate temporal and spatial scale for managing resources. Based on the INTELLIGENT RIVERÂ®, this observation instrument comprises in situ sensors that form an expansive intelligent fabric. The instrument enables a new
1. Sensing Fabric: serves as the instrument lens and comprises multiple sensor networks.
2. Transit and Uplink System: responsible for relaying the data from the lens to a high-performance computing backbone.
3. Observation Management Middleware: responsible for normalizing data, ensuring validity, and routing the resulting data streams to end users applications
4. Repository and Presentation Services: serves as an instrument eyepiece and comprises an extensible set of applications.
The design of the goals in 1 include broad support for interconnect standards, support for high-fidelity sensing, scalable temporal and spatial coverage, rapid and reliable deployment, and system longevity. In 2, these goals include adaptability to diverse environments, coverage scalability, fault-tolerant data transport, and low cost operating expense. Scalability, real-time performance, and fault-tolerant, secure messaging are included in 3. The default instrument package in 4 includes an application for archiving observation data to common scientific data formats and presenting that data to a broad audience of end-users, including scientists, educators, ecosystem managers, and legislative policy makers.
It is evident that the growing mismatch between water supply and demand impacts us all: USA watersheds are in peril! This project does something about it with support from EPA and USAGE. Within the reach of environmental science, this work explores the connections among land use, energy production, climate effects, and water resources applying information and computing systems. The design, construction, and deployment of the instrument along the full reach of the Savanna River and two adjacent watersheds, covering a broad range of physical and chemical parameters should yield significant research contributions applicable to other watersheds and across subdisciplines, from sensor networking, to operating system design to cloud computing, to high performance ecosystem visualization. When complete, the instrument should enable a new class of data-intensive environmental ecological programs, ranging from fine-scale studies of river transport phenomenon to assessments of hydroelectric impacts on greenhouse gas concentrations, as well as the validation of kinetic-based quality models. Moreover, the instrument should yield significant research contributions in the areas of sensor networking, operating system, cloud computing, and high-performance ecosystem visualization.
Broader Impacts:
The impact should be felt both regionally and nationally. At the national level, the instrument should initiate a transformative shift towards real-time management. At the local level the instrument will contribute to initiate two new degree programs, creating collaborative ties with other institutions, and serve as an outreach hub that links regional high schools and museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water is the planet's most precious natural resource, fundamental not only to human health, but economic prosperity. This simple observation has startling consequences when viewed in light of the growing incongruity between water supplies and water demand. Population growth, industrialization, and climate change are putting the nation's water resources at risk, from the dwindling aquifers in California's Central Valley to the nutrient loaded waters of Florida's Lake Okeechobee. The impact can be catastrophic, disrupting local ecosystems, decimating native species, stifling energy production, damaging food crops, and compromising human health. Safeguarding these fragile resources for the benefit of future generations requires high-quality environmental data at unprecedented scales. With the support of the National Science Foundation (CNS-1541917), Florida Atlantic University, Clemson University, and Coastal Carolina University built and deployed a new sensing instrument to provide this data. 

We call this landscape-scale sensing instrument the Intelligent River (R). It is composed of a heterogeneous fabric of wireless sensors that cover an expansive geographic area. The integrated toolset enables end-users to collect, share, and utilize a broad spectrum of environmental data at unprecedented temporal and spatial scales. The design comprises new data acquisition platforms, wireless transmission technology, data processing and storage systems, and data presentation tools. The resulting instrument enables fine-grained, long-lived, low-cost environmental monitoring and supports meaningful analyses of the acquired data.

The instrument was deployed along a stretch of more than 250 river miles along the Savannah River, running from the headwaters in the Blue Ridge mountains down to river mile 27, near the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to instrumentation of the mainstem of the river, the deployment included instrumentation of three watersheds, two at dense scales. The deployment phase of the project began in July of 2013, with technology extensions and enhancements proceeding in parallel. 

The application opportunities for the technology developed under this award are numerous. This potential makes it possible to pool resources across multiple strategic partners to ensure longterm operation of the instrument, safeguarding the National Science Foundation's investment. Over the project period, the Intelligent River (R) has been deployed (1) within the Savannah River to support basin-scale water quantity and quality management (NSF-funded); (2) within the City of Aiken, SC to assess green infrastructure practices for managing stormwater (EPA/ARRA-funded, City-funded); (3) within the Hunnicutt Creek Watershed in Clemson, SC, to support stream and wetland mitigation activities; (4) within Strawberry Swamp at the Baruch Institute of Coastal Ecology in Georgetown, SC, to support wetland assessment activities; and (5) within the agricultural fields of the Edisto Research and Education Center in Blackville, SC to support precision agriculture initiatives designed to reduce water usage and agricultural pollutants. The system also serves as a cornerstone of the Charleston Vertical Farm study (EPA-funded). Today, the instrument remains in use for stormwater management in South Carolina, water quality monitoring in both South Carolina and Florida, and atmospheric monitoring along the Atlantic Coast. The most recent expansion was in Puerto Rico. The Intelligent River (R) offers a unified technology platform with unbounded operational potential.
